ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned in depth visual analysis skills and how they connect with literary analysis skills. We also got a wonderful overview about how themes from American history are relevant for the modern day.

This course gave me an excellent survey of American art, and I felt that I developed the skills for describing and interpreting paintings and portraits as well as looking at them in a social and historical context
I learned how to evaluate artistic pieces and use what I captured to understand the artist and their historical/cultural moment.
A great overview of different trends/movements in American art pre-Civil War. Also learned how to "close read," analyze, and write about art, how to curate a museum exhibit.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The professor is the main strength! Professor Wolf is so kind and thoughtful and always available to help. 

The only thing that could have been improved is I wish we could have spent more time in the art gallery!

Strengths: Professor Wolf is one of the best professors I've ever had. His discussions are always engaging, and he really cares about his students and genuinely wants us to appreciate art in our own ways. The workload is incredibly manageable and I always came away from each class feeling inspired
Weaknesses: There were only two graded assignments which put a lot of pressure on both assignments.
This course is amazing. It is an incredibly reasonable workload and is honestly a ton of fun. Professor Wolf is a gem. It is unclear as to what goes into your grade at the end but take this class!

Strengths: fascinating material, a manageable workload, and a unique final project that is far more engaging than writing a traditional paper
Weaknesses: conversation sometimes dragged a bit when we spent a very long time on a single piece of artpace could be quickened a bit.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the Zoom seminar worked well because there was a limited number of students and everyone was actively engaged.

This class worked well over Zoom! We mostly looked at art via shared screen, which allowed us to really scrutinize each image, but it took away from the fun of getting to see people's reactions and have a true conversation. The class at times felt more like a lecture than a discussion seminar beacuse of that

I thought our virtual discussions were often highly engaging, but focusing closely on particular pieces of art over Zoom can be exhausting, so sometimes it was hard to maintain focus in those portions of the class. Again, I think this might be a question of needing a slightly quicker pace/more varied learning formats (breakout rooms, perhaps?) specifically because it was an online semester and it was much harder to stay engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, absolutely. Professor Wolf is fantastic and the class is engaging and fun. The assignments are broad enough so assignments can be tailored to individual interests, making them always pleasant to work on. The course material is also worth studying and does a good job of not overwhelming, yet presenting lots of material.

I could not recommend this course more highly! Anyone who has an interest in American history, literature, or art should take this course for a new perspective and deepening of analytical skills as well as the opportunity to learn from an absolutely incredible professor.

Yes!!! Professor Wolf is so amazing, and as someone who took art history for the first time with this class, I can tell you you won't regret it. The class is endlessly inspiring, and I felt that I learned a lot about history in a way I wouldn't have in a normal history class. The imaginary exhibition assignment is also a great opportunity to be creative
Absolutely take this course. It's a ton of fun and is not a source of stress. The learning environment was great when I took it, and the professor is super accessible.
If you are interested in close analysis of art (and some literature) from the pre-Civil War period, and/or learning a bit about what it's like to be a museum curator, definitely take this course!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
